How Writing on Medium Helps My Academic Day Job

The unexpected benefits of blogging

Craig Harper
Mar 28

I’ve been blogging on Medium (on and off) for around a year, and it’s having some unexpected benefits in my professional life.

When I’m not writing here I’m typically doing my day job. I’m an academic psychologist, teaching and working in the UK.

September-December is my really busy time, when 70% of my teaching is timetabled. The other 30% takes place between January-May, followed by an intense marking period, and the inevitable admin associated with a minority of unhappy students discontent with their outcomes, and grade moderation. Add to this the pressure to publish research articles, supervise student projects, and engage in broader communication about scientific evidence, it’s a really high pressured and year-round role.

Write for a lay audience, and everyone will understand your argument

For a while, I’ve been looking for a way to streamline how I do some of this role. The easiest way to do this is to start to write popular reviews of new research studies. Let me explain…

When writing a review of a new study, it’s possible to clarify my thoughts about a particular topic, explore particular methods for answering different questions, and learn how to write in a straightforward, understandable way. Doing these things have unintended consequences in a number of ways:

  1. By writing these reviews, I keep up-to-date with the latest research findings in the topics I work on;
  2. Learning to distill complex scientific information into short 4-minute reads helps me to ‘get to the point’ — this is invaluable when talking to students about research, and helping them to understand the latest developments in the areas that I teach about;
  3. Communicating about research that I am interested in helps me to identify potentially topical, interesting, and fruitful research avenues, as well as potential collaborators in this work;
  4. Writing on Medium and its various publications gives me access to a huge audience. According to Ev Williams’ columns, this platform has upwards of 80 million unique visitors per month. This has massive implications for science communication, and lets me talk to thousands of people about my own and others’ research findings.

Take for example the following article:

It's Official - Trigger Warnings Might Actually Be Harmful
New study confirms the fears of Lukianoff and Haidtmedium.com

This is my most-read article on Medium. At the time of writing it has 34k views (with a 29% read rate) and 3893 claps from 415 fans.

I wrote it in response to a published academic article about the use of trigger warnings. In essence, it found that participants who received trigger warnings were significantly more likely (compared to those in the control condition) to experience emotional distress after trauma.

On the back of this, I was able to think more deeply about research design and the implications of these findings. I’m also now leading a team via the open science StudySwap platform to replicate and extend this work in light of the original study’s limitations.

In short, I would encourage academics to use blogging as a way to clarify their thoughts, hone their writing skills, curate stories related to their expertise, and communicate with the public about their science. The skills I’ve gained and the networks that I’ve formed on the back of this have been invaluable in raising both my skills and my professional profile.

It takes guts to put your thoughts down on screen to begin with, but it’s a great opportunity for professors and students to develop transferable skills that can help them in their everyday practice.

Craig Harper is a Senior Lecturer in Psychology. His research examines responses to sexual crime, and political decision-making. You can find out more by following on Twitter and Medium.
